questions.text: Which of the following is not an example of the clinical importance of enzyme induction?

options.label: A
options.text: Phenobarbitone is used in the treatment of neonatal jaundice

options.label: B
options.text: Phenytoin is contraindicated in acute intermittent porphyria

options.label: C
options.text: Tolerance occurs to anticonvulsant action of carbamazepine in few doses

options.label: D
options.text: Omeprazole increases metabolism and thus inhibits the action of clopidogrel

questions.correct_answer: D. Omeprazole increases metabolism and thus inhibits the action of clopidogrel
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Omeprazole increases the metabolism and thus inhibits the action of clopidogrel.

Educational Objective:

Conversely, enzyme inhibition , such as the interaction between omeprazole and clopidogrel, can significantly impact drug efficacy.

questions.text: Experiments show that 50% of an oral 100-mg dose of Drug A is absorbed in a 60-kg test subject. However, the fractional bioavailability was only 0.2. Assuming a liver blood flow of 1500 mL/min, which of the following is the hepatic clearance of Drug A in this situation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 900 mL/min

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Absorption and Bioavailability : 50% of the 100 mg dose of Drug A is absorbed, so 50 mg reaches the liver. The fractional bioavailability (F) is 0.2 , meaning 20% of the absorbed drug reaches the systemic circulation , or 20 mg . Amount Extracted by the Liver : 50 mg of the absorbed drug reaches the liver, and 20 mg exits into the systemic circulation. Therefore, the amount extracted by the liver is: 50 mg − 20  mg = 30 mg Hepatic Extraction Ratio (ER) : The hepatic extraction ratio is the fraction of the drug extracted by the liver : ER = Amount extracted by the liver/Amount reaching the liver = 30 mg / 50 mg = 0.6 Hepatic Clearance (Clₕ) : Hepatic clearance is given by the formula: CL = Liver Blood Flow (Q) × Extraction Ratio Given that the liver blood flow (Q) is 1500 mL/min (or 1.5 L/min) and the extraction ratio (ER) is 0.6 : CL = 1500 mL/min × 0.6 = 900 mL/min

questions.text: Which of the following drugs would most likely need a loading dose to help reach therapeutic levels?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Digitoxin, t1/2= 161 hrs

Explanation:

  • • Aspirin (t½ = 15 minutes) : Aspirin has a very short half-life, meaning it rapidly reaches steady-state levels with regular dosing. A loading dose is typically unnecessary because the drug accumulates quickly.
  • • Aspirin (t½ = 15 minutes)
  • • Acetaminophen (t½ = 2 hours) : While acetaminophen has a longer half-life compared to aspirin, it still reaches therapeutic levels relatively quickly with regular dosing, making a loading dose unnecessary.
  • • Acetaminophen (t½ = 2 hours)
  • • Adenosine (t½ = 10 seconds) : Adenosine has an extremely short half-life and is used for acute, rapid-onset effects, such as in the treatment of supraventricular tachycardia. Because of its immediate action and short duration, no loading dose is needed.
  • • Adenosine (t½ = 10 seconds)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Drugs with a long half-life (such as digitoxin) require a loading dose to achieve therapeutic concentrations quickly. This is particularly important in clinical scenarios where immediate drug effects are needed. For drugs with short half-lives, a loading dose is typically unnecessary because steady-state levels are rapidly reached with regular dosing.
  • ➤ long half-life
  • ➤ loading dose
